results.title: How to take the right risks: the manager as decision maker
results.creator_credit: Pare Lorentz Jr, BNA Communications and Ameron
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Manager and the Organization”.
All decisions involve an element of risk. The issues must be carefully defined and all alternatives considered. Also if it is not an isolated incident, it is desirable to establish a policy for dealing with similar situations. Narrated by Peter Drucker.

results.title: How to supervise
results.creator_credit: David Pitt, Francis Gysin and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: Defines the responsibilities of the supervisor and reinforces the need for a civilised relationship between supervisor and trainee, by giving hints for supervisors on how they should attend to the training and safety of young entrants under their charge. Although made for the coal industry most of the ideas are generally applicable.

results.title: How to Successfully Manage Your Time
results.brief_description: Practical examples of time management for office workers and business people make this instructional program most useful. It shows the effective time management techniques “How to spend your time”, “How to organise your time”, “How to eliminate time wasters”.

results.title: How to steal a million
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Fred Kohlmar and World Wide Productions
results.brief_description: How to steal a million is a romantic comedy caper film that re-teams star Audrey Hepburn and director William Wyler thirteen years after their classic film “Roman holiday” was made. “How to steal a million” is set among the high-end fine art world of museums, collectors, dealers and con-artists. Audrey Hepburn plays Nicole Bonnet, who’s father Charles (Hugh Griffith) specialises in art fraud, in particular ‘lost’ van Gogh masterpieces, which go on to command high prices at auction. Charles’ prized (fake) Cellini sculpture, Venus, is loaned for a public exhibition in Paris. Fearing that her father’s forgery will be discovered Nicole enlists the help of renowned art thief Simon Dermott (Peter O’Toole) to steal the sculpture. O’Toole plays the charming thief and Hepburn’s love interest with aplomb. The Paris setting and couture clothes (by Givenchy) for Hepburn make “How to steal a million” a delight to watch. Also stars Eli Wallach with a guest appearance by Charles Boyer.

results.title: How to stay alive
results.creator_credit: Alan Landsburg, Alan Landsburg Productions and ABC News (US)
results.brief_description: Warning signals of heart disease show up in eight major areas of physical health. These danger signals are dramatised by documenting the lifestyles of five apparently healthy middle-aged men who are candidates for heart attacks. Each man’s doctor prescribes a change of living pattern that will greatly reduce the risk, and the extent to which the five accept their individual lifesaving prescriptions is shown. Narrated by Robert Young.

results.title: How to Sell to Australia
results.brief_description: Since the beginning of television, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche through harnessing the moving image. Advertisers haven’t just sold products to Australian audiences, they’ve also built community, spread iconic catchphrases and created beloved characters.

constellations_primary.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
constellations_primary.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million views on YouTube with the campaign’s song known globally, having charted on iTunes in 28 countries. While light-hearted, at its core the hugely successful commercial carries a serious message: Be Safe Around Trains.

results.description: Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.
description_for_label: Advertising in Australia is unique, innovative and has a language all its own. Since the beginning of television in 1956 to today, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche by harnessing the power of the moving image. Through animation, live-action and apps, advertisers have been able to not just sell products to Australian audiences but also build community, spread iconic catchphrases and create beloved characters.

results.title: How to run a lathe
results.brief_description: Based on the book “How to run a lathe”. Explains how the lathe is essential to construction of anything containing metal— cars, ships, planes etc. Goes on the explain the parts of the lathe and how to operate them. Aimed at operators and machinists rather then general interest.

results.title: How to reduce drag (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Education Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Fluid Dynamics of Drag”.
Professor Ascher M. Shapiro indicates the effect of body shape on drag; streamlining at high Reynolds Number; Bernoulli’s principle; boundary - layer stall; effect of turbulence on stall; effect of roughness; streamlining at low Reynolds Number; resolution of the paradoxes of Part I.

results.title: How to read plays
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Literature Appreciation”.
The suggestions in this film for reading a play emphasise imaginative reconstruction of the stage production, thus enabling the reader to grasp the visual, aural and dramatic content of a play from the written page.
